basics.name: Basem Jawahri
basics.label: Senior Front End Developer
basics.summary: I am a front end developer with over fourteen years of experience in technology looking for opportunities at companies that are vibrant, energetic and willing to embrace cutting edge technology. I have the technical knowhow to pick up new technology and methodologies and a keen eye for good code.

work.summary: I was a part of the home services team, responsible for driving over 72% of the online business revenue. I was one of three senior front end developers on this team. Starting at Centrica, I learned and used Ember.js within a few days. For everything we did in the team we applied test driven development with the use of Qunit and Yadda to write acceptance, integration and unit tests. We used the Wunderflow Git workflow along with continuous integration and continuous deployment within a two week sprint cycle.

projects.title: Service contract adjustments
projects.description: I was involved in a team working on a greenfield project to allow British Gas service customers modify, cancel or renew their contract online. This involved communication with AWS hosted

projects.title: The Ford Foundation
projects.description: The Ford Foundation is an independent, non-profit grant-making organization and the second largest philanthropy in the United States. I was involved in a revamp of their website, working closely with back-end, design and QA. The solution is built on an Umbraco platform with an angular client side presenting translatable views. The grant-making database consumes data from a REST API and translates that data into a single page application where charts are drawn to represent the data given. These charts interact with other parts of the solution combining the data provided by the service and data provided by the CMS.

projects.title: Vodafone Digital Workplace
projects.description: Developed the Vodafone Digital Workplace for Vodafone internal use which consisted of a collection of provider hosted SharePoint apps in Office 365. The workplace is used by over 100,000 Vodafone employees globally and supported in sixteen languages. The client side is a SPA built on Angular with a per client customizable grid like the Windows tiles but more options in app dimensions. The workplace is where each user can add, remove, reposition and resize any of the apps within the Vodafone app store. The app store is also part of this build where each app is a separate module that interacts with the workspace and sibling modules. In the styling front, everything is mobile first HTML5/CSS3 with considerations for touch events.

work.summary: I started my front end developer career at ClearPeople.

projects.title: National Autistic Society
projects.description: This was an on-going project which involved a lot of adding and tweaking of site features, so the XHTML, CSS and JavaScript libraries had to be very well maintained to avoid problems. Accessibility and browser compatibility were very important to this client due to the nature of its target audience which meant that fall-backs were always put in place for new features and thorough testing was done before any deployment. As the front end lead, I was in charge of planning the structure and setting up the Sitecore page layouts, sub-layouts and what we called “blocks” for this very flexible site. The blocks can be setup differently and placed within the homepage or any other page, including the e-commerce and checkout process pages. This also applies to the Sitecore modules used on the site such as the web forms for marketer’s module styled to fit anywhere the client wished. Along with this flexibility came the risk of site editors making mistakes so I was in char the Sitecore security setup on the solution based on inheritance of roles and domains for the microsites within the setup.

projects.title: SEGA
projects.description: This SEGA project was for a Microsoft SharePoint intranet publishing site with a very challenging design which included a custom jQuery carousel with AJAX functionality, some custom web parts and as much branding of vanilla SharePoint features as possible. With a new master page, page layouts, menus and a lot of customization to the SharePoint ribbon deployed, I was able to go to the client offices and carry out a training session for the new users which included instructions on how to manage the site and the already available social networking features of SharePoint.

projects.title: Stena Lines
projects.description: Stena recognized the opportunity to upgrade the websites of four of their business units from Microsoft CMS 2002 to SharePoint 2010. This was to be done in a manner that the transition was seamless to the site visitors. Rather than migrating all of the styling from the previous solution, we brought in what was relevant and cleaned it up. A lot of this was then modified in order to work with the various SharePoint controls such as the navigation and breadcrumbs etc.
